rating_criteria.description: Cervical spine rated under General Rating Formula for Diseases and Injuries of the Spine
rating_criteria.formula: General Rating Formula for Diseases and Injuries of the Spine

levels.criteria: Forward flexion of the cervical spine greater than 30 degrees but not greater than 40 degrees; OR combined range of motion of the cervical spine greater than 170 degrees but not greater than 335 degrees; OR muscle spasm, guarding, or localized tenderness not resulting in abnormal gait or abnormal spinal contour; OR vertebral body fracture with loss of 50% or more of the height

Forward flexion of the cervical spine greater than 15 degrees but not greater than 30 degrees; OR combined range of motion of the cervical spine not greater than 170 degrees; OR muscle spasm or guarding severe enough to result in abnormal gait or abnormal spinal contour such as scoliosis, reversed lordosis, or abnormal kyphosis
Forward flexion of the cervical spine 15 degrees or less; OR favorable ankylosis of the entire cervical spine
Unfavorable ankylosis of the entire cervical spine
Unfavorable ankylosis of the entire spine (cervical + thoracolumbar)

rom_calculation.description: Combined ROM = Flexion + Extension + Left Lat Flexion + Right Lat Flexion + Left Rotation + Right Rotation

ivds_formula.description: Intervertebral Disc Syndrome (IVDS) can be rated under this formula if more favorable
ivds_formula.note: Same IVDS formula as thoracolumbar spine

levels.criteria: Incapacitating episodes having a total duration of at least 1 week but less than 2 weeks during the past 12 months
Incapacitating episodes having a total duration of at least 2 weeks but less than 4 weeks during the past 12 months
Incapacitating episodes having a total duration of at least 4 weeks but less than 6 weeks during the past 12 months
Incapacitating episodes having a total duration of at least 6 weeks during the past 12 months

ivds_formula.incapacitating_episode_definition: Period of acute signs and symptoms requiring bed rest PRESCRIBED BY A PHYSICIAN

radiculopathy.description: Nerve root compression causing symptoms in arms/hands
common_symptoms: Pain radiating into shoulder, arm, or hand
radiculopathy.rating_note: Each affected side rated separately under peripheral nerve codes

headaches.description: Cervicogenic headaches secondary to neck condition

myelopathy.description: Spinal cord compression causing neurological deficits

tips_for_veterans: Describe your WORST days, not average days
Report all symptoms: pain, stiffness, limited motion
Mention pain radiating into arms or hands (radiculopathy)
Document any numbness, tingling, or weakness in arms/hands
Report headaches that may be related to neck condition
Describe how neck affects daily activities and work
Mention if you've had steroid injections or surgery
Report any muscle spasms and their frequency
Don't push through pain during ROM testing
Ask examiner to document ROM during flare-ups
CLAIM RADICULOPATHY SEPARATELY if you have arm symptoms
common_mistakes: Not claiming radiculopathy as secondary condition
Not describing arm/hand symptoms (may be radiculopathy)
Failing to document how condition affects work
important_notes: Cervical and thoracolumbar spine are rated separately
Radiculopathy (arm symptoms) rated SEPARATELY from spine
Each radicular nerve group is rated individually
Painful motion warrants at least minimum rating
Flare-up ROM must be estimated by examiner
IVDS formula may provide higher rating if applicable
Incapacitating episodes require physician-prescribed bed rest
